title-group.article-title: The intellectual structure of organizational ambidexterity: A bibliographic investigation into the state of the art

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The recent development of the ambidexterity theme stems from the recognition that firms today increasingly have to deal with contrasting and conflicting goals such as incremental vs. radical innovation, exploration vs. exploitation (March, 1991), alignment vs. adaptability (Gibson and Birkinshaw, 2004), and many others. Understanding and managing tensions as well as succeeding in simultaneously accomplishing high levels of both the poles causing such tensions are essential to firms’ competitiveness and survival (O’Reilly and Tushman, 2004, 2008). Organizations able to do so possess the ambidexterity capability, namely the capability of a complex and adaptive system to achieve and manage conflicting activities, by realizing high levels of both in a simultaneous way.

Although ambidexterity capability is a relatively young theme in literature, today it has become a central concept in management research, receiving many contributions from various research streams. Since the pioneering work of Tushman and O’Reilly (1996), the ambidexterity construct has been used in many managerial and academic papers. If we examine these papers, we can see that almost all agree that ambidexterity is an organizational capability that makes it possible to resolve different tensions that arise within an organization. Several types of tensions (e.g., alignment vs. adaptability, comfort of the past vs. uncertainty of the future, exploration vs. exploitation of business, exploitation vs. exploration of knowledge) are taken into consideration by these papers thus making the ambidexterity literature seem quite fragmented. This discrepancy in the types of tensions considered is largely due to the fact that the concept of ambidexterity has been used in many fields, and each time assumes a different theoretical literature stream as reference (see Raisch and Birkinshaw [2008] for a detailed description of these literature fields). In such a scenario, characterized by seemingly disordered development across different areas of research, a number of interesting questions arise:

list-item.p: What is the intellectual structure of the ambidexterity literature?
Is there a relationship between the intellectual structure of the ambidexterity literature and the tensions analyzed in the papers?
How does such a structure reflect the richness of papers’ theoretical approaches?

sec.p: Answering these questions allows us to tidy up our collective understanding of ambidexterity and to identify the directions for future research. To this end, we conducted a bibliometric analysis of the intellectual structure of the ambidexterity field (Nerur et al., 2008; Ramos-Rodríguez and Ruíz-Navarro, 2004), taking the ‘core’ papers into consideration, namely those papers that can be truly considered as providing a key contribution to the development of the ambidexterity construct.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: To identify works using the ambidexterity construct, we began our analysis by retrieving all papers that were published in three main databases (ISI Web of Science, Business Source Premier, Science Direct) with titles, abstracts, keywords, subject or full text containing the expressions ‘ambidexterity’ or ‘ambidextrous.’ This preliminary literature search yielded approximately 2000 papers. We reviewed these articles to exclude those that do not refer directly to managerial or organizational topics. We then decided to limit our articles only to works published in journals covered in the ISI Journal Citation Reports, as these are likely to have the highest impact in the field (Podsakoff et al., 2005) and to consider only papers published after Tushman and O’Reilly published their seminal paper in 1996.

A total of 137 articles met these selection criteria as of June 2011. These papers treat the ambidexterity issue in different levels of detail: in some papers, for example, ambidexterity figures merely as a citation. So, in order to identify the intellectual core of ambidexterity, i.e., what can be truly considered as the core set of the most influential contributions, we used a method inspired by the work of Lane et al. (2006). By following their procedure, we grouped the 137 sample papers into four categories according to the centrality of the ambidexterity construct to the paper’s core topic. The categories are as follows: (1) extend the construct definition; (2) centered on the construct and its dynamics; (3) construct considered in hypotheses and/or model; (4) construct a minor citation with little or no discussion. Two researchers in our team independently classified the papers according to these categories, with the results shown in Table 1. Following Lane et al. (2006), we limited our analysis to the 55 articles in categories 1, 2, and 3, thus constituting the core of the field.

sec.p: In order to answer our questions, we carried out a bibliographic coupling analysis, using the Sitkis and Ucinet softwares, and then performed factor analysis. This analysis allowed us to cluster the core articles into related groups, which represent subfields of the ambidexterity theme (Appendix A presents details on the methods applied), making it possible on the one hand to objectively identify the subfields of the ambidexterity literature (the intellectual structure), and on the other hand to provide the ground for the identification of literature gaps and then suggest useful insights for future research.

sec.title: Findings from the factor analysis
sec.p: Factor analysis allowed us to objectively identify the ambidexterity subfields that correspond to the four factors extracted as shown in Table 2 and Figure 1. After analyzing the content of the papers included in each factor, we labeled them: (1) Foundations: Structural solution, (2) Contextual solution, (3) Antecedents and consequences of ambidexterity, and (4) Cross-boundary perspectives. Papers that load on more than one factor are related secondarily to additional factors. Table 3 describes the most important features of the papers included in each factor, which we interpret in more detail below.

sec.title: Foundations: Structural solution (Factor 1)
sec.p: This factor comprises the structural center of the ambidexterity domain and it is heavily weighted towards the papers that received the greatest number of citations within our sample: this is indicative of the fact that these are the foundational papers within the field. They deal with the issue of ‘Structural ambidexterity,’ the first organizational solution proposed by Tushman and O’Reilly (1996), which advocates for a physical separation between opposing activities via loosely coupled and differentiated units, each of which is specialized in pursuing one specific goal through the development of different competencies, systems, incentives, processes, and cultures. The factor reveals the key issues and concerns within the body of research on structural ambidexterity: it is suggestive of the structural separation required for managing tensions within the organization, and of the pivotal role for managers in enabling integration and in maintaining the connections between different units.

sec.title: Contextual solution (Factor 2)
sec.p: The second factor encompasses, among others, the papers of Gibson and Birkinshaw (2004) and Birkinshaw and Gibson (2004), the first authors who formally introduce another form of the organizational solution to cope with tensions and paradoxes: the contextual one. They show that ambidexterity may arise from features of the organizational context in terms of cultural values and norms rather than from implementing dual structures. In their view, ambidexterity is not so much realized at the structural level, but rather at individual levels. Provided with a favorable context, individuals are in fact indirectly pushed towards organizing their working time so as to integrate both opposite activities in the course of their daily tasks. Therefore, while the structural definition posits dual structures as the means to achieve ambidexterity, the contextual definition proposes building a carefully selected set of systems and processes that ‘enable and encourage individuals to make their own judgments about how to divide their time between antagonistic demands’ (Gibson and Birkinshaw, 2004: 210).

sec.title: Antecedents and consequences of ambidexterity (Factor 3)
sec.p: This factor contains the greatest number of papers in our sample (11 of 55). The papers, published in 2009 and 2010, mainly concern the provision of a better understanding of the antecedents and consequences of ambidexterity, both from the theoretical and empirical perspective. We analyzed these 11 papers, distinguishing those that focus on the enabling factors of ambidexterity, those factors that serve as an impetus for the development of ambidexterity, from studies investigating the consequences of ambidexterity.

Looking first at the enabling factors, formal and informal structural mechanisms, culture, context, and managers’ characteristics are the main elements investigated as possible solutions for different kinds of tensions. As we can see from Table 3, most of these papers analyze a specific typology of enablers, adopting both a quantitative and qualitative approach and choosing either the firm and/or the team as the level of analysis; the studies are for the most part conducted by following a cross-sectional approach, and there is a lack of longitudinal research.

Turning to the consequences, one of the reasons behind the growing interest in the ambidexterity capability is the evidence of a positive link between this capability and firm performance. As a consequence a large number of empirical papers, chiefly based on quantitative analysis carried out at firm level, have tested such relationships. Financial and firm performances are the most studied dependent variables; more recent works have started analyzing the impact of different structures on innovation performances.

sec.title: Cross-boundary perspectives (Factor 4)
sec.p: The previous factors are widely recognized in the literature and have in common the adoption of an internal perspective in analyzing ambidexterity. More recently, however, thanks to the expansion of the ambidexterity theme to open innovation and operations management literature, a new perspective seems to emerge: an external one. This last factor, comprised of three recent articles, may signal a new area of inquiry in which ambidexterity is analyzed by adopting a broader perspective that goes beyond organizational boundaries. Ambidexterity, according to these authors, arises from the firm’s openness towards cooperation with partners, suppliers, distributors, regulators, and competitors both at home and abroad.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results of our analysis depict the intellectual structure of ambidexterity as well as answer our motivating questions and suggest useful insights for future research.

What is the intellectual structure of the ambidexterity literature? We have identified a four-factor model describing the intellectual structure of the ambidexterity literature. This model supports the findings of previous literature reviews by using an objective procedure thus reducing subjectivity to a minimum. An interesting and new result of the analysis regards the fourth factor, where tensions can be resolved by opening up firm boundaries to include external actors; particularly in the operations field, future studies could investigate whether backward and forward strategies support the resolution of tensions, thus making a firm ambidextrous.

Is there a relationship between the intellectual structure of the ambidexterity literature and the tensions analyzed in the papers? How does such a structure reflect the richness of theoretical approaches? The four-factor solution mainly deals with structural and contextual solutions, enablers and consequences of organizational ambidexterity and it does not seem to be directly related to the different tensions and theoretical frameworks advocated by the papers; as a consequence, the solutions (both structural and contextual) proposed by the authors appear useful for solving different kinds of tensions, as Table 3 shows. Similarly, the antecedents of organizational ambidexterity (Factor 3) could be used to manage different typologies of paradoxes (incremental vs. radical innovations, emergent vs. mature strategies, explorative vs. exploitative learning, etc.), linked to different theoretical approaches. In other words, the solutions proposed by the different papers to make firms ambidextrous emerge from a macro level of analysis where general organizational mechanisms for facing tensions are suggested without going in depth into the specific unit where the tension arises; specific processes, mechanisms, and routines that are directly involved in the tensions solution are not taken into consideration by these papers, with few exceptions (Adler et al., 1999).

These observations suggest that the organizational ambidexterity literature has departed from the original definition of the construct as a capability for resolving tensions. A capability is comprised of ‘high level routines and key inputs which together confer a set of decision options to produce an expected output’ (Parmigiani and Howard-Grenville, 2011: 419). Taking this perspective means looking inside a specific tension, identifying the routines that, as ‘repetitious organizational activities … along with other resources and in combination with each other’ (Parmigiani and Howard-Grenville, 2011: 419), make it possible to develop the capability of resolving that tension.

Future research may therefore benefit from a return to the construct’s definition, which emphasizes the nature of ambidexterity as a capability. This approach implies analyzing ambidexterity at a more micro level, through the organizational practices and routines lens to discover the artifacts and processes underlying the development of this capability (Kim and Rhee, 2009). Adopting, for example, a ‘practice-centered’ approach in order to explore ambidexterity, ‘to enter into how things get done in organizations’ (Antonacopoulou and Pesqueux, 2010: 11), would be a useful tool for investigating ambidexterity and providing a micro-foundation for this multifaceted phenomenon. Case-based analysis may also better reveal the complexity of this phenomenon, as may a narrower unit of analysis that makes it possible to explore the ‘how’ of the phenomenon.

As Table 3 shows, prior research on ambidexterity focused at the macro level, such as the firm or business unit, is plentiful, while empirical studies that examine the construct at a more micro level are scarce. Shifting attention from the macro to the micro – a single organizational process, project, or phase (new product development, for example) – would enable study of the solutions firms find to resolve specific tensions. A smaller unit of analysis allows the researcher to discover the organizational routines and practices mentioned above that lead to the development of the ambidexterity capability (Litchfield and Gentry, 2010).

Longitudinal studies, also meager (see again Table 3), are recommended in order to shed light on how ambidexterity coevolves, dynamically, with changes in the environment. To date, studies on ambidexterity have mainly adopted a cross-sectional approach that does not capture the evolution of the phenomenon. Organizations are adaptive systems, in continuous interaction with their environments; as a consequence, organizations continuously reconfigure their activities and designs in order to face external changes and thus resolve the tensions that continuously arise. It is highly probable that ambidextrous organizations adapt their designs over time rendering the ambidexterity capability a dynamic capability.

sec.title: The future of ambidexterity research
sec.p: The previous analysis shows that recently there has been growing interest in ambidexterity from different areas of research, and therefore addressing different typologies of tensions. Is this flourishing of the literature the result of firms perceiving a real need to be ambidextrous or is it merely a recent fad in academic literature? We suspect the former, since firms increasingly need to be ambidextrous. Could the current ambidextrous models suggested by the literature be useful for firms? Some questions are still very open: do we expect different ambidextrous models for different tensions? How do these ambidextrous models both stimulate change and evolve along with the organization? How does the context shape ambidextrous models?

To answer these questions, we believe that future studies should view ambidexterity as a capability rather than as a thing that is wholly divorced from the specific context in which tensions arise: until now there has been a prevalence of black box approaches to ambidexterity and the fine-grained, multilayered nature of routines and capabilities has been almost entirely ignored. It is now time to investigate how ambidexterity really emerges from the context by looking at the internal working of specific routines, which could provide the micro-foundations and key mechanisms used by firms to resolve tensions. Clarification is needed also on the organizational level at which ambidexterity takes place: is ambidexterity an attribute of an individual? Is ambidexterity an attribute of either the whole organization or of the single unit? How do every day individual actors shape exploitation and exploration organizational routines? Do these ambidextrous routines permit change and work as a dynamic capability?
To take our knowledge of ambidexterity one step further forward we need to answer all these questions.

app.title: Appendix A: Bibliographic coupling and factor analysis
app.p: Bibliographic coupling and factor analysis techniques have been employed to identify the internal structure of the ambidexterity theme. In particular, with bibliographic coupling analysis we have obtained a quantification of the proximity between the papers in our sample and by running a factor analysis we have identified a number of factors which represent the literature subfields. Figure 2, adapted from McCain (1990), summarizes the steps that have been followed in this study.

Bibliographic coupling technique was introduced by Kessler in 1963 and represents one of the key historical antecedents of co-citation analysis. The technique gives the measure of the relation between two papers. Based on the assumption that it is probable that two papers with many common references are reporting on a similar research topic, the bibliographic coupling strength between two papers is defined as the number of common references cited by both papers. Two papers are thus related because they cite the same third text (Jarneving, 2005, 2007).

Bibliographic coupling begins with a mathematical representation of the links between papers and the references that they cite through the construction of the paper–reference matrix: the rows in the matrix correspond to papers in the sample while the columns correspond to the all references (Morris, 2005). The elements of the matrix are equal to 1 if a paper cites a particular reference, 0 otherwise.

The next step is to construct the bibliographic coupling matrix. This matrix is a symmetric matrix that lists the number of common references cited by two different papers in the sample. The diagonal of this matrix contains the counts of the number of references cited in each paper. The raw bibliographic coupling matrix is then converted into a matrix of Pearson’s correlation coefficients. Correlation coefficients represent a measure of similarity between two works. They are preferred to frequencies, since they make it possible to standardize the data, thus providing a better basis for subsequent statistical analyses (Rowlands, 1999).

The last step of bibliographic coupling analysis involves applying various multivariate techniques to analyze the data, and interpret the findings. In this study, we make use of factor analysis to explore the underlying structures of the interrelationships between the selected papers. Factor analysis allows the core articles to be classified into related sets, called factors, by detecting the structure based on varying degrees of relatedness among the articles. The factors comprise relatively homogeneous groupings of articles that may represent a subfield, research front, or community of interest.

Factors were extracted by principal component analysis (PCA) and their number was extracted following the Kaiser criterion (Kaiser, 1960). To clarify the loadings, which represent the correlation between a given article and the factor, or the degree to which the article belongs to that set, the components were rotated using the varimax rotation method for its simplicity and rigor (Nunally, 1978): it in fact attempts to maximize the variance of squared loadings on a factor (i.e., to produce some high loadings and some low loadings for each factor). Consistent with prior studies (McCain, 1990), we include only factor loadings higher than 0.4; papers with loadings of 0.7 or greater are likely to be useful in interpreting the factor and consequently they are ranked within the factor on which they load around 0.7 or greater. Whenever a paper loads positively on more than one factor (with loadings from 0.4 to 0.7), this indicates that such a document extends its sphere of influence beyond one field; it serves as a bridge between two or more factors (fields).

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Anna Nosella is a Professor of Business Strategy at the University of Padova, Faculty of Engineering. Her main research interest focuses on innovation management, dynamic capabilities, and strategies. Professor Nosella’s research has been published in Technovation, Long Range Planning, Management Decision, Journal of Engineering and Technology Management, Journal of Business Research, and International Journal of Human Resource Management. She acts as reviewer for many journals such as California Management Review, Journal of Organizational Change Management, Technology Analysis, and Strategic Management. Address: University of Padova, Department of Managerial Engineering, Stradella San Nicola, 3, 36100, Vicenza, Italy. [email: anna.nosella@unipd.it]

Silvia Cantarello is a lecturer in economics at Trieste University, Faculty of Engineering. Her main research interest focuses on human research management, organization, and innovation management. She has published articles in reviewed journals such as: Management Decision, International Journal of Human Resource Management, and Creativity and Innovation Management. She also works as project manager in an insurance company where she is involved in an international reorganization project. Address: University of Padova, Department of Managerial Engineering, Stradella San Nicola, 3, 36100, Vicenza, Italy. [email: silvia.cantarello@unipd.it]

Roberto Filippini is a Professor of Management at Padua University. He teaches management of innovation at the Faculty of Engineering and Management and new product development at the MBA and EMBA of the CUOA Business School. His interests mainly concern the topic of innovation, new product development, and knowledge management. He has dealt with these topics both from a theoretical and empirical point of view. He has published articles in journals such as: Journal of Product Innovation Management, Journal of Operations Management, International Journal of Production Research, International Journal of Operations and Production Management, International Journal of Production Economics, International Journal of Technology Management, and IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management. Address: University of Padova, Department of Managerial Engineering, Stradella San Nicola, 3, 36100, Vicenza, Italy. [email: roberto.filippini@unipd.it]
